title.hi: The following Poem is the Product
of Ireland; it was occasion'd by
deavouring to get an Act to divide

titleStmt.title: was rejected by the Irish House of
Commons.

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: OLD Latimer preaching did fairly describe
A B──────who rul'd all the rest of his tribe;
And who is this B────? and where does he dwell?
Why truly 'tis Satan, Archb────of hell:
And he was a primate, and he wore a mitre,
Surrounded with jewels of sulphur and nitre.
How nearly this ──────our ──────resembles!
But his has the odds, who believes, and who trembles.
Cou'd you see his grim face, for a pound to a penny,
You'd swear it must be the baboon of Kil────
Poor Satan will think the comparison odious,
I wish I could find him out one more commodious;
But this I am sure the most rev'rend old dragon
Has got on the bench many ----- suffragan;
And all men believe he pr-----es there incog.
To give them, by turns, an invisible jog.Our ──────puft up with wealth and pride
To hell on the backs of the clergy wou'd ride;
They mounted and labour'd with whip and with spur,
In vain────for the devil a parson wou'd stir.
So the commons unhors'd them, and this was their doom,
On their cro────s to ride, like a witch on a bro
Tho' they gallop so fast, on the road you may find 'em,
And have left us but three out of twenty behind 'em.
Lord B──'s good grace, lord C────r, and lord H────d,
In spight of the devil wou'd still be untoward.
They came of good blood, and cou'd not endure
Their former companions shou'd beg at their door.
When Christ was betray'd to Pilate the praetor,
In a dozen apostles but one prov'd a traitor!
One traitor alone, and faithful eleven;
But w-- can afford you six t──────in seven.
What a clutter with clippings, dividings and cleavings,
And the clergy forsooth must take up with their leavings.
If making divisions was all their intent,
We thank them, they've done it, but not as they meant;
And so may such ──────for ever divide,
That no honest heathen wou'd be on their side.
How shou'd we rejoice, if, like Judas the first,
Those splitters of parsons in sunder should burst?
Now hear an allusion!────a mitre, you know,
Is divided above, but united below.
If this you consider, our emblem is right,
The ────────divide, but the clergy unite.
Shou'd the bottom be split, our ────────would dread
That the mitre will never stick fast on their head,
And yet they have learnt the chief art of a sovereign,
As Machiavel taught 'em, divide and ye govern.
But courage, my l────, tho' it cannot be said
That one cloven tongue ever sat on your head,
I'll hold you a groat, and I wish I cou'd see it,
If your stockings were off, you cou'd shew cloven f--t.But hold, cry the ────, and give us fair play;
Before you condemn us, hear what we can say.
What truer affection cou'd ever be shewn,
Than saving your souls, by damning our own.
And have we not practis'd all methods to gain you?
With the tyth of the tyth of the tyths to maintain you;
Provided a fund for building your spittles,
You are only to live four years without vittles!
Content, my good l────ds, but let us change hands;
First take you our tythes, and give us your lands:
So God bless the church, and three of our m────es;
And God bless the commons, for biting the bitters.803-33LI
